content: how do i work around the edges tutorial demonstrates single_crochet edging with one stitch per row your pattern may call for different stitches and spacing a when you reach the end of the last row of the body of the work turn the piece on it s side and look at the construction of the stitch you will be working in to this demo is single_crochet so there is only one twist the taller the stitch the more the yarn twists depending on your pattern instructions you may or may not be attaching new yarn at this point for this demo i am attaching a second color locate your starting point do any yarn overs needed for your stitch and insert the hook into the side of the stitch i try to get only one strand of yarn over the hook for this work but that is not always possible draw up a loop and complete your first stitch you may be told to work around the post of the stitch in some patterns as this gives a more open look to the joining area creating a lacy effect and separating the edging a bit from the main body of the work other times you may want to make this connection as seamless as possible the second stitch is worked into the side of the next row just as you would work into the next stitch if you were working across the top of the work for this demo you should when you get to the bottom of the work have the same number of stitches as you have row in that area for some patterns the directions will be to work evenly around this is because of the differing stitch heights we are working into single_crochet row so one stitch per row is what we need copperscaledragon@yahoo com copperscaledrago ravelry user id
